traction is key, tourqe of the motor is instant and insane but is limited to the traction of the tyre on the road, the motors exceed this traction massively so power available is severely limited by the traction control systems, the power is still there it just dosent/can't use it. think of a drag car, huge low pressure soft sticky tyres give that extra traction to accelerate faster from the standstill with that huge motor sitting on the rear axell to add weigh and "traction". Take your 10 thrusters, arrange them so they push down vertically on each wheel you in essence give the car massively heavy wheels and increase the friction of the tyre on the road. Since it already accelerates forward at about 1.5g, the return on any amount of downforce is roughly 1.5 times higher than pointing the thrusters laterally, assuming torque is no limit...AND that would help in turns also. So what makes the most sense to me is trusters either only on top, or on top and bottom, but not any thruster in fully lateral directions.

If you want it really controllable in the air, which makes sense even for accidental jumps, I can imagine using variations in placement and direction of the thrusters, still facing generally up or down, to provide pitch, roll and yaw control so you don't land upside down or sideways. If you want really powerful ability to resist aero effects that could backflip or nosedive a jumping car at speed you need to match the top thusters with bottom thrusters far to the front and back for maximum torque and that means you may be getting to a point where the flying thing is within reach, especially if you then deliberately angle the car up a bit for aero lift. My speculation is that this is how they got there - to the point of thinking about flying cars I mean....5g-1g thrusters on both the top and the bottom, but none for lateral thrust makes the most sense and could achieve amazing things now that we are allowing ourselves to dream :D - one of the these advantages would be sub 1s to 100km/h even for 1 extra g of downforce if my in head math is right.

The physics says the thrusters will all face up to add down force. Since traction exceeds the friction limit of the force normal, each unit of down force gives more than a unit of force for braking, turning, and acceleration. The limiting factors are the load rating of the tires, the motor/battery power, and the size of the brakes. Within these limiting factors a down force adds more acceleration than simply trusting the car forward.

If you're happy for cars to do 250mph+ on the roads, what would it matter if they did 300mph+. You start running into centripetal forces issues in the wheel materials. Rubber isn't up to it. Speed record rocket cars run on tyreless aluminium wheels. Just say you have a COPV about 4 feet long and  1.5 feet wide inside (cylinder with dome shaped ends). I make that 10700 cubic inches (it's easier in S.I... 170,000CC = 170 litres. A litre is 1.75 UK pints. US pints are 16fl oz. brit pints are 20fl oz. Makes 2.2 US pints per litre makes 170 litres 370 pints. Divide 8 for (US) gallons. Thing is the COPVs are good for well over 300 bar apparently, so you can multily the contents by 300. A final point is that as you compress the air, it will heat up in the tank and as it does work by reexpanding in the thruster it will cool back down. They will presumably expend air a lot faster than it can be compressed, so the thrusters will run cooler than ambient temperature.

Why NOT have some gas thrusters on the car, for acceleration, and could be re-oriented for a quick hop?  They can be throttled independently, and use a small cheap and simple flight controller.  Thrusters of this type have been used to actually fly experimental test vehicles before, and are ideal for testing, because of their reliability, and ease of setup. the relatively light weight would make them a great addition to an existing car design, but would likely be totally spent (or nearly so) in just a few seconds of use.   In this case, long enough to dramatically improve the drag times on a car. could even be varied, or fired to help keep the car under control when approaching the max coefficient of friction for the tires.

I haven’t checked all of Tim’s math but assuming that the stock roadster has an acceleration of 1.44g and that it is limited by tyre grip we can go faster by increasing downforce rather that adding horizontal force.

Tyre grip is a product of friction and friction is directly proportional to how hard the two surfaces are pushed together. Push harder you get more grip.
Acceleration is based on Mass (not to be confused with weight).

Pushing the car down increases the available grip between the tyre and the road without increasing the mass of the car.
If the car is grip limited (ie the motor still has more power to give) and stock acceleration exceeds 1g it means the most efficient way to improve acceleration is to point the thrusters up – note: this has the additional advantage of improving breaking too.

Now calculate the required trust downwards to produce a 0 – 60mph of 1.0sec
Assuming W is the weight of the car then the trust required T = 1.32xW/1.44 or for Tim’s 3000lb roadster about 2750lb of thrust a saving of 1210lbs.
One final caveat – This assumes that the car is 4WD, and that the motors have an additional 90% spare power, and that acceleration is uniform, and that the tyres and the road have sufficient internal shear capacity, etc, etc…

You're making a bad assumption that cars accelerate at a constant rate.  For reasons of motor torque characteristics, suspension loading, and the visco-elastic nature of tires, they do not.  Rockets have constant force but not constant acceleration due to their change in mass.  Even if you have enough data to account for this, you can't have enough to characterize the car's acceleration from the tires and you can't simply add the accelerations together to get a 0-60 time.  The roadster has enough torque to spin its wheels.  It likely has enough power to do so up to 60 MPH.  The better use of thrusters would be to increase downforce to the maximum available from the tires and suspension to allow the use of the extra torque and power from the motors.  Any left over thruster capacity could then be used for acceleration directly.

This is batshit crazy, there's no way that you'll ever produce enough thrust to substantially overcome the extra weight you'll need to carry. Mythbusters tried to build a boat powered by nitrogen tanks, got almost zero thrust with every type of nozzle they tried, the gas velocity is just too slow and there isn't anything for it to push against.
I thought they already did that. Remember the roadster with three boosters going towards Mars.

So we already have batteries that can explode if punctured. Sure let’s add 6 containers of highly pressurized gas to it. I can’t imagine anything that would go wrong in a crash. Even on a track car this wouldn’t really be a good idea. Mainly because the system wouldn’t even last a lap on a small track unless the tank was huge. Sure it would grip better but the whole thing would add a good bit a weight to the car and throw off its distribution. which means more weight would have to be added to compensate for the tank and thrusters.

Oh and about the motorcycle. Just for reference a low side crash is when the rear tire of a bike looses traction and slides out from under the rider sending them sliding across the pavement. A high side crash is when the rear tire loses traction then regains it within a second, flinging the rider off the bike. It would take one hell of a rider to recover from a low side with that system. At best a lucky recovery. At worst you turn a low side into a high side. Then what if the system fails? You then have an explosive that could send shrapnel into the rider or pedestrians. I don’t even want to think about the cost of refilling the containers plus the the time it takes to pull the fairing off and possibly removing the container itself.

In theory it sounds like a good idea but in, reality you end up with something that has the potential to add a lot of dangers and cost.
If you want to be safe on a bike just ride within your limits and ride atgat. (all the gear all the time)

Rockets aren't hard. It's the compressor that's hard. Bauer makes a compressor that can compress 3500 litres of air every minute to the required pressure. It draws 72 kW, so it's about the size that we're talking to absorb regen energy. It weighs 1950 kg, or nearly as much as a Model S. To fill a 45 litre 350 bar cylinder would take 4.5 minutes. Even if he can make a compressor 1/10th the size and the same power, (which is probably impossible due to the heat rejection) it's still 200 kg. Rockets are easy, an electric compressor that can do this, very very very hard.

By angling the thrusters upward, they would create down force to multiply their effect through the tires. Effectiveness due to vertical thrust would be proportional to the friction coefficient times the sine of the thruster angle. The horizontal reduction in thrust, which is proportional to one minus the cosine of the thruster angle would be less...until a certain angle was reached of course.

comment_text: The car probably isn't using much of it's power during low speed acceleration because it's fighting for grip. A stock car with the Roadster's performance numbers does not need cold gas thrusters for everyday driving. It's already ridiculously overpowered for street-legal use, and it won't need any help to out-duel any stock ICE vehicle on the planet. Further, performance-impacting cold gas jets will be strong enough to strip paint or take off your skin, and at very low temperatures to boot; no regulatory authority is going to approve such a thing for street-legal uses.

But I don't think that's where Elon Musk is aiming. I think he has in mind track racing. And I don't think he'll put half the thrusters aiming out the back, either. What race drivers most lust for is control, not acceleration.

Gas thrusters that prevent the car from spinning out on a hard turn, that help slow the vehicle in emergencies, that provide a modest boost to acceleration (for a vehicle that's already over-endowed with acceleration, you don't need much of a boost), distributed all around the vehicle, is what I think Musk is considering.

It makes perfect sense to put the COPV in the vehicle where the rear seats are if the vehicle is going to be used for track racing.

And really, this is what the new Roadster is about. Musk is going to offer a stock race car that is simply better than anything on existing stock car racing circuits. He is going to take a wrecking ball to ICE vehicle bragging rights, which is pretty much the purpose of stock car racing in the first place. Big name auto companies play in the racing game to inspire consumer lust for their production cars. Equipping his Roadsters with cold-gas thrusters as a racing option just rubs salt in those wounds; he'll have a car that can handle tough track conditions with less concern about losing control than any other vehicle.

The SpaceX 'secret sauce' isn't really so much in the COPV or thrusters. It's in the software and algorithms. Using SpaceX tech, an on-board computer will figure out exactly when thrust is needed to enhance control, and do so many times every second. Depending on available thrust, COPV capacity, pressure and circumstances, it is indeed possible for a vehicle to 'jump' and land safely. I could see a Roadster jumping over an unfolding accident just ahead. Crazy to think of it, but really, it's technically no more challenging than landing first stage boosters on a postage stamp in the middle of a heaving ocean. Can you imagine it? The first time a Tesla hops over a dangerous accident in a race, the world of racing will be forever changed.

The problem with this number is that it is misleading. The roadster can't hit 60 mph in 1.9.

They are counting on a one foot roll off, which means that the car will be able to accelerate just over 6 mph in this foot and that is about 10% of 60 mph.
This means that we have to add 10% (0.19 sec) to the 1.9 sec acceleration run and that lands you roughly at 2.1 sec which just a tad slower than the theoretical fastest time to 60. engineering explained have calculated this a long time ago

Hi Everyday Astronaut , not for getting away from Tesla and SpaceX, but there is a spacecraft (fictional but VERY plausible) that I would like you to make a video of and hear your thoughts about it.
This spacecraft is the ZERO-X featured in the Thunderbirds Are Go movie of 1966. This ginormous spacecraft (and for ginormous I mean 400m of length) is designed to reach mars and get back and also be fully reusable. It is composed by 5 main components: the Main Body, that has the main chemical rocket engines; two "lifting bodies", basically two gigantic radio-controlled flying wings (200m of wingspan) used to propel the zero-x through the atmosphere and are then detached and flied back to earth when the spacecraft has reached space and the chemical engines are ignited; the MEV or Mars Exploration Vehicle, used to explore mars while the Main Body stays in orbit; and finally the Nose Cone, which is used the make the spacecraft more areodynamic during the ascent (it si not used when the zero-x comes back while the lifting bodied are reatached via remote control).
Here is a link to the full movie ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LOlF-_16G-g&t=364s ) and to the wiki ( http://thunderbirds.wikia.com/wiki/Zero_X ).
Please make a video of this marvelous spacecraft, it is my favourite out of all science-fiction.
I also think that it is the most plausible fully reusable spacecraft because we could actually make with the technologies that we have today, only problem being the cost and I quote from the movie: "... this project has been the most costly yet devised by man"

The air tank could be used for more than propulsion.
If it's just used for energy storage anyway, and has reached the minimum pressure levels for rocketry, then anything over that is kinda free power storage. It could be used for heating and cooling for example (and when cooling it could generate power for the batteries!). The air compressor could heat a thermal accumulator -- perhaps some sort of phase-change material like wax -- and expanding air could be bled off to freeze a similar material in a different accumulator. Dunno if the weight and complexity make it worth the energy savings, but it could be done. It could also provide positive air pressure to the cabin in case of vehicle submersion, so allow it to float longer, or indeed propel the vehicle in short bursts if it does find itself floating. It could deploy a ring-type arrangement with small holes facing rearward that release air - dragging water along with it. This is proven technology for moving liquids (and Dyson even uses a version in some of their fans) and could make the Roadster quite capable in the water.
What else... there's always pneumatic tools large and small, water generation (so you hardly have to fill the wiper fluid), CPAP machine reservoir!, seat cooling, and of course - air horns. Big ones.
